text: The ironic thing is that the author points out NumFocus as evidence that Python's data ecosystem is well funded, whereas not only is the Julia project funded by NumFocus, but JuMP and SciML are as well.

elements.text: The ironic thing is that the author points out NumFocus as evidence that Python's data ecosystem is well funded, whereas not only is the Julia project funded by NumFocus, but JuMP and SciML are as well.

text: To get real, though, it's really hard to get a feeling of how many people actually use Julia, and whether this number is increasing. These programming language rankings have woefully inadequate methodologies. To be honest, I'm not even sure he is wrong

elements.text: To get real, though, it's really hard to get a feeling of how many people actually use Julia, and whether this number is increasing. These programming language rankings have woefully inadequate methodologies. To be honest, I'm not even sure he is wrong

text: Looking at new members in the forums, GitHub interactions and downloads there doesn't seem to be any slowing down AFAICT. The premise of this article just seems to be that it's not as popular as some legacy systems and Python/R yet, so it must be dead.

text:
> It was going to run like C, seamlessly integrate with Fortran, do things R does without its clunkiness, look and read like Python and be homoiconic like Lisp.

But it *does run like C, seamlessly integrate with Fortran etc etc..
